awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Investigating the incorporation of elements into ice in Lake St. Clair during extreme weather conditions: an analogy for chemical cycling in the Arctic Ocean
awd_abstract_narration:
Sea ice plays an important role in the chemical cycling of elements and compounds in the Arctic Ocean. Material can be concentrated from the water, from sediments, and from the atmosphere into ice as it forms near shore, and as it is transported by currents into the open ocean. The processes by which many elements are incorporated into sea ice as it forms are poorly understood, however, in part because it requires being on site and sampling as the ice forms. The recent occurrence of very cold weather in the midwestern U.S. provided an opportunity to study these processes in large lakes, that can then be used to advance our understanding of sea ice. The RAPID funding mechanism allows a quick response to this unique weather event, at much lower cost than would be required to mount a similar study of Arctic sea ice. This study will take place in Lake St. Clair and surrounding rivers near Detroit, between Lakes Huron and Erie. The project will involve several undergraduate students and a graduate student. 

To investigate the mechanism of incorporation of particle-reactive species into ice, the investigators will collect and analyze a suite of lake ice samples (ice thickness > 12 inches) from Lake St. Clair and rivers that discharge into Lake St. Clair as well as precipitation (both snow and rain) for 210Pb, 210Po and 7Be in southeast Michigan. The objective is to quantify the spatial and temporal variations of the activities of these isotopes in different sediment grain-sizes trapped in ice collected from different sites. The results from this study are anticipated to provide insights in answering two fundamental questions: i) what is the mechanism that leads to the enrichment (>100 times in some cases) of 210Pb and 7Be in sediments incorporated in ice (both in fresh water and seawater); and ii) how does the 210Po/210Pb activity ratio vary in sediment-depleted ice compared to sediment-laden ice? Since 7Be is completely derived from atmospheric deposition and ice-rafted sediment is highly enriched in 7Be, how much of the 210Po (210Po/210Pb < 0.1 in precipitation and in aerosol) in sediment- laden ice is derived from atmospheric deposition and from surface water? In addition, the study will involve collection of snow and atmospheric aerosols through the remainder of the winter, to understand atmospheric deposition of isotopes to ice and the lake surface.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of the fundamental questions in the Arctic is the role of sea ice in the transport of sediments and sediment-laden organic and inorganic chemical species from the coastal Arctic to the interior. The major mechanism by which large amounts of sediment entrained into the ice cover is through incorporation of suspended sedimentary particles in frazil ice. The goal of this study is to investigate the mechanism of incorporation of atmospherically-delivered Be-7, Pb-210 and Po-210 during a snow storm into suspended particulate matter in Lake St. Clair in southeast Michigan and compare it to the radionuclide incorporation mechanism in the Arctic Ocean.

With a group of six undergraduate and two graduate students, we collected 20 different lake ice samples from Lake St. Clair in SE Michigan during a historic snowstorm and snow events between January and March 2019, brought those to the shore-based laboratory and allowed the samples to melt at room temperature. The grain-size separated sediment and water from ice-melt were analyzed for Be-7, Pb-210, Ra-226, and Cs-137 by gamma-ray spectrometry and Po-210 by alpha spectrometry.

The major outcomes of this study are:

i) The activity of excess Pb-210 varied from 16 to 876 dpm/g, the largest range observed in any sedimentary material; in 3 different sites in the Lake, the activities were found to be >500 dpm/g which is about 100 times higher than the values reported in surficial sediments of Lake St. Clair. The Pb-210 activity in lake ice also varied over two orders of magnitude, from 22 to 3,347 dpm/100 L, again the largest range reported in any natural lacustrine system.

ii) The Po-210/Pb-210 activity ratios in lake ice varied from 0.01 to 0.36. The variations in the ratio indicates the extent of recycling of Po-210 and Pb-210 derived from atmospheric deposition and resuspension of fine sedimentary material at the sediment-water interface. The Po-210 in lake ice varied over two order of magnitude, from 2.0 to 333 dpm/100 L, the highest range reported in any natural environment.

iii) The Be-7 activity in ice-rafted sediment in < 32 mm varied between 32 and 6,294 dpm/g and to our knowledge, this is the highest activity every reported in literature. The Be-7 activity in lake ice varied over a factor of 440, from 46 to 20,253 dpm/100L, the largest range reported. Since all the Be-7 is derived from atmospheric deposition, it is evident that most of the Be-7 incorporated in sediment is derived from atmospheric deposition during a heavy Snow storm.

iv) The activity ratios of excess Po-210/Pb-210 and Be-7/excess Pb-210 varied between 0.10 to 0.61 and 1.1 to 7.9, respectively. The Be-7/Pb-210 activity ratio in lake ice samples varied from 1.4 to 6.1, again suggesting variations in the source of these nuclides, either atmospherically delivered or resuspended material from sediment-water interface, causing the variations in the activity ratios.

v) Atmospheric depositional fluxes of Be-7, Pb-210 and Po-210 are similar to long-term study conducted about 20 years ago and the Po-210/Pb-210 in precipitation are similar. 

The enrichment of particle-reactive species in ice-rafted sediment takes place in a relatively short timescale which is puzzling. It appears that the same mechanism might be leading to high enrichment of Pb-210 in ice-rafted sediment incorporated in sea ice. Thus, this study paves the way for understanding the mechanism of incorporation of metals and other particle-reactive contaminants in sea ice. A large enrichment in ice-rafted sediment indicates potential accumulation and enrichment of other atmospherically-delivered organic and inorganic pollutants. The Po-210/Pb-210 activity ratios in lake ice and ice sediments are intriguing, and the ratios observed in this study are similar to the values found in the ice-rafted sediments collected in the interior Arctic Ocean.
